title: generally better on the ninth century than the tenth, and placing too much emphasis on Amalfi to the exclusion of the Byzantine provinces and the principalities of Capua and Benevento. (See my review in American Historical Review xcviii
430-1.) There are much briefer discussions in English in the chapter on the south in Chris Wickham’s excellent Early Medieval Italy
Southern Italy in the tenth century’

note: and Culture et Societe en Italie Byzantine (VIe-XIe siecle
title: is the fundamental study of the administration of the Byzantine provinces. There is also an Italian version of this work

note: Huguette Taviani-G arozzi, La Principaute lombarde
title: but only one of these is in English (reprinted from Dumbarton Oaks Papers xxviii
On the Lombard principalities there is Nicola Cilento, Le Origini della signoria Capuana nella Langobardia minore
largely about the ninth century, and the same author’s essays reprinted in his Italia meridionale longobarda

Pouvoir et societe en Italie lombarde meridionale (1991) is a lengthy, discursive and over-schematic monograph, but with some very important insights contained within it, especially in the later chapters

note: is seminal. R. Poupardin, Etude sur les institutions politiques et administratives des principautes lombardes de UItalie meridionale
title: Mito di una citta meridionale (1977) is a fine study of the town of Salerno in the Lombard period. On the other principalities, Jean-Marie Martin, ‘Elements prefeodaux dans les principautes de Benevent et de Gapoue (fin du VIII siecle-debut du XI siecle): modalites de privatisation du pouvoir’, in Structures feodales et feodalisme dans I’Occident mediterraneen (X -XHIe siecles
is also useful, despite its age. P. Skinner, Family Power in Southern Italy

container-title: Vincenzo al Volturno: two volumes have been published so far
note: with two more to follow. For the period of the conquest John Julius Norwich, The Normans in the South 1 0 1 6 -1 1 3 0 (1967) provides a splendidly written, if at times overimaginative, narrative. For a minutely detailed scholarly narrative F.
title: The Duchy of Gaeta and its Neighbours 8 5 0 —1139 (1995) is an excellent mono­ graph which makes important comparisons between the different coastal duchies. On Amalfitan trade there are useful articles (in English) by A.O. Citarella in Speculum xlii
299-312, and Journal of Economic History xxviii
Scholars are now laying considerable emphasis on the wealth of Lombard south Italy, as for example in A.O

The Ninth-Century Treasure of Monte Cassino in the Context of the Political and Economic Developments in Southern Italy (Miscellanea Cassinese 50, 1983). But our understanding of that wealth has been especially enhanced by the archaeological investigation conducted by the British School at Rome at S

container-title: Chalandon’s chapter in the original Cambridge Medieval History

the UTET Storia dTtalia (1983)). On the early history of the Normans and Italy (up to 1042) there is a useful book by Salvatore Tramontana, I Normanni in Italia. Linee di recerca sui primi insediamenti i Aspetti politici e militari (Messina 1970): to the best of my knowledge no second volume has appeared. The best study of the coming of the Normans remains Hartmut Hoffmann, ‘Die Anfange der Normannen in Unteritalien’, QFIAB xlix
note: There are also useful articles in T H E AGE OF R O B E R T G U I S C A R D
title: La Domination normande en Italie et en Sicile (1907) remains un­ rivalled, although on some points of detail his work has inevitably been superseded by more modern studies

will eventually be replaced by one by G.A. Loud, when the New Cambridge Medieval History, iv, is finally pub­ lished. See also the lengthy chapters by Vera von Falkenhausen and Salvatore Tramontana in II Mezzogiorno dai Bizantini a Federico //

author.literal: and John France, in Journal of Medieval History xvii

title: English on the same subject by Einar Joranson, in Speculum xxiii

185-205, although Chapter II of this book presents a very different interpretation from those advanced by these authors. A similar critique is offered in Chap­ ter Three of Dione Clementi, £Stepping stones in the making of the “regno” ’
offers a valu­ able synthesis of the social history of the Mezzogiorno, but the ambitious

container-title: Loud, Conquerors and Churchmen in Norman Italy (1999), and Leon-Robert Menager, Hommes et Institutions de VItalie normande
note: Relazioni e communicazioni nelle prime giornate normanno-sveve, Bari maggio 1973) (1975). This volume initiated a series of the proceedings of the biennial conference at Bari, where much of the most interesting work on Norman Italy has been published in recent years. The second in the series, Ruggero il gran conte e rinizio dello stato normanno
title: reader should consult the same author’s La Pouille du Vie au X II siecle
a massive and comprehensive monograph on Byzantine and Norman Apulia which is probably the most important single work published about early medieval southern Italy since Chalandon’s in

The chapters on settle­ ment, the economy and agriculture are especially good. On a similar scale is Laurent Feller, Les Abruzzes medievales. Territoire, economie, et societe en Italie centrale du IXe au X lle siecle
although the main focus of this is on the pre-Norman period. The impact of the Norman conquest on south Italian society is the primary theme of the articles reprinted in G.A
Probably the most important piece in this last collection was the prosopography of Normans and other Frenchmen attested in south Italian sources first published in Roberto il Guiscardo e il suo tempo

note: More recent volumes of these proceedings have been de­ voted to themes, usually socio-economic, rather than chronological periods.
title: includes Tramontana’s important study of the aristocracy of early Norman Sicily
The first of these thematic
in­ cludes a pioneering study of crops and agriculture by Jean-Marie Martin

container-title: and consequently there are numerous other volumes of conference proceedings, often of very variable quality and published years after the gathering actually took place
title: The most recent
was devoted to how Norman Italy was perceived from other regions. Italian professors are even more addicted to conferences than are academics from other countries

container-title: One further recent multi­ author volume should be noted: Cavalieri alia conquista del Sud. Studi sullTtalia normanna in memoria di Leon-Robert Menager
title: which publishes the proceedings of a conference to mark the 900th anniversary of the duke’s death, is one of the weaker of the breed. It does, however, contain a brief but important essay by Horst Enzensberger, the leading scholar of Italo-Norman diplomatic, on Guiscard’s chancery

container-title: Errico Cuozzo has also writ­ ten a number of careful studies of particular lordships, some of which have been revised and republished in his Normanni, nobilita e cavalleria (Salerno 1995). Evelyn Jamison, Studies on the History of Medieval Sicily and South Italy
note: contains important essays on the aristocracy by the doyenne of English-language scholars of the Norman era, but the principal focus of her interests was the twelfth century rather than the period of the conquest. Claude Cahen, Le Regime feodal de I'Italie normande
title: which includes essays on a number of aspects of the conquest, by (among others
A last item on social history is an import and pioneering study by Patricia Skinner, Health and Medicine in Early Medieval Southern Italy
On the aristocracy, Wolfgang Jahn, Untersuchungen zur normannischer Herrschaft in Siiditalien (1040-1100

is careful and thoughtful, and has valuable appendices listing the surviving documents from individual lordships; as will be apparent from the footnotes to Chapter VI, I have found his discussion of the revolts against Guiscard extremely useful

container-title: by Norbert Kamp in the Forme di potere volume

and by C.D. Fonseca, ‘L’Organizzazione ecclesiastica dell’Italia normanna tra l’XI e il XII secolo. I nuovi assetti istituzionale’, in LTstituzione ecclesiastiche della £Societas Christianay dei secoli X
note: The Greek Church is discussed in the essays by Guillou (above) and by L.-R. Menager in Revue d’Histoire ecclesiastique liii (1958) and liv (1959), reprinted in his Hommes et Institutions de ITtalie normande (above). Studies of the Church are, however, more abundant on monasticism.
title: Untersuchungen zu ihren lehnsrechtlichen und kirchenpolitischen Beziehungen (1972) is thorough, thoughtful, brilliant in part, and often perverse. The early chapters are the best, but the emphasis on the so-called ‘feudal’ aspects of the relationship is overdone. There are very useful reviews of this work, in English, by Helene Wieruszowski in Speculum
Ian Robinson has also drawn heavily upon Deer’s book for his chapter on southern Italy in The Papacy 1073-1198
However, the other key work on this subject is H.E.J. Cowdrey, The Age of Abbot Desiderius. Montecassino, the Papacy and the Normans in the Eleventh and Early Twelfth Centuries
a masterly and wide-ranging study. Readers will also profit from P
The Papal State in the Middle Ages and Early Renaissance
chapters 4-5, in which the south Italian Normans play a significant part, and a useful article (in English) by Dione Clementi in BISIM E lxxx
A comprehensive study of the south Italian Church in the Norman era is still to be written. There are, however, useful studies of the Church in particular regions: notably by

deals with the papacy and with Montecassino, as well as with the secular Church and such issues as patronage by the lay nobility. The changes wrought to the secular Church by the conquest are also discussed in two important articles in Italian

note: This accomplished and prolific author has published two further volumes of collected papers, most of which deal with ecclesiastical, and especially monastic, history, Tra Roma e Palermo. Aspetti e momenti del
title: There is a useful, if brief, general essay on south Italian monasticism in the early chapters of Hubert Houben, Die Abtei Venosa und das Monchtum im normannisch-staufischen Siiditalien
which also gives the best and most thorough discussion of the Hautevilles’ house monastery; to a large extent superseding the study by L.-R. Menager in QFIAB xl
A number of Houben’s essays on Venosa can be found (in Italian) in his Medioevo monastico meridionale

note: Apart from the book by Cowdrey (above), there are also Herbert Bloch’s three massive volumes, Montecassino in the Middle Ages (1986
title: Menager also studied Roger I’s foundation at Mileto in Bolletino delUarchivio paleograjico italiano n.s
But the abbey which has been most written about is Montecassino, and on this subject there is (for once) an abundant liter­ ature in English

container-title: Fabiani, La Terra di S. Benedetto
note: published in the abbey’s own historical series, Miscellanea Cassinese, other volumes of which include important textual editions. H. Dormeier, Montecassino und die Laien im 11. und 12.
title: - less comprehensive than its title might suggest, but still immensely valu­ able. John Howe, Church Reform and Social Change in Eleventh-Century Italy. Dominic of Sora and his Patrons (1997) studies a small congregation which was later absorbed into the Cassinese empire, and has some interesting comments on Montecassino’s continued links with the Lombard aristocracy of the Abruzzi, while Francis Newton, The Scriptorium and Library at Monte Cassino
supersedes all previous studies of Cassinese intellectual activity. On Montecassino’s property and its administration see L

note: reprinted in Conquerors and Churchmen in Norman Italy (above).

in the principality of Salerno comes in Dr Ramseyer’s as yet unpublished thesis (University of Chicago 1996). For monasticism on the island of Sicily, L.T. White, Latin T HE AGE OF R O B E R T G U I S C A R D
title: is another book less wide-ranging than the title might imply, but is none the less useful, especially on the expansion of the Cassinese congregation. A number of studies concerning this abbey and the Norman conquest, and others devoted to its erstwhile daughter-house of St Sophia, Benevento, are reprinted in G.A. Loud, Montecassino and Benevento in the Middle Ages (to be published in
The easiest introduction to the other great Lombard monastery, S. Trinita di Cava, is probably another essay by G.A
This abbey is also discussed by Taviani-Carozzi in the last chapter of her book on the principality of Salerno, and in an important essay by Valerie Ramseyer in Anglo-Norman Studies xvii
The most detailed discussion of Cava and the Church
remains valuable, as does M

note: is densely written but thought-provoking; its principal focus is, however, on the period after the conquest, as is also the case with Hiroshi Takayama, The Administration of the Norman Kingdom of
title: There is unfortunately not much to recommend on Islamic Sicily and the Norman conquest
A History of Islamic Sicily (1975) has only a little to say on the conquest and thereafter

note: Unfortunately none of these con­ temporary histories from Norman Italy has as yet appeared in English translation, though the edition of William of Apulia by Marguerite Mathieu (see the list of abbreviations at the head of this volume) has a good French translation. An English version of Amatus of Montecassino, by Prescott Dunbar, is, however, in preparation.
title: The forthcoming book by Jeremy Johns on the Muslims of Sicily under the Normans is eagerly awaited. Art and architecture have not featured much in this book: had space not been at a premium they might have done more. Those interested should still look to the classic study by Emile Bertaux, L ’A rt dans ITtalie meridionale

Romanesque Sculpture in Campania. Patrons, Programmes and Style (1991) is important, and has excellent illustrations. In Italian there are important essays by Valentino Pace, most of which are scattered among conference proceedings. The chroniclers of the conquest have been studied in an interesting but flawed book by
